reviewText: I was excited for the movie when I saw that it starred the phenomenally talented Tom Hardy. My hopes were high, but wasn't sure what to expect. It was better than I ever could have imagined. The entire cast was stellar. It was so well paced throughout the entire film. It was suspenseful, dramatically engaging, and humorous at the perfect moments. The violence was very intense and realistic. Couldn't speak more highly of this film. It's a must see!

LAWLESS, the second collaboration between Director John Hillcoat and Writer/Composer/All-Around Weird Dude Nick Cave, is a film that has just about everything working in its favor: It has a trememdous cast, some excellent and vibrant performances, some crackling scenes of dialogue and some beautiful scene composition. So why can't I get past everything that it doesn't have that it needed to put it on the same level as their first collaborative effort, an amazing and little-seen film called THE PROPOSITION?

LAWLESS, based on a book of non-fiction called "The Wettest County In The World", is based during the later years of Prohibition in Franklin County, Virginia and based around the Bondurant brothers, who became a little less than folk-heroes and a little more than outlaws during those years. They, like many of the families in Franklin County, are Moonshiners and they're pretty good at it. The eldest, Howard (Jason Clarke, most recognizable for his recent turn in the excellent but short-lived THE CHICAGO CODE) is a strong-armed but dull-witted man who samples a little too much of his own product. The middle child is Forrest (Tom Hardy, best known for just about every other film in the last two years), who is something of a legend amongst the community already for being "immortal", by surviving the illness that killed their parents when he was just a boy. Jack (Shia LaBeouf, discarding most of his annoying mannerisms here) is "the runt of the litter", skinny and scared, but brainy and ambitious and anxious to prove his worth in the family business to Forrest who really runs the show. They are put upon by a Federal agent or "Special Deputy" named Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce, who also starred in THE PROPOSITION) who is looking not to clean things up Eliot Ness style, but looking to make a buck by shaking down the locals for protection money. This leads the local law to side, at least for a while, with Rakes, as Jack and his best friend Cricket (Dane Dehaan) look to sell their goods to a big-time gangster (Gary Oldman) and also romance a young preacher's daughter (Mia Wasikowska). Another unusual visitor comes to town in the visage of Maggie (Jessica Chastain), looking to escape the hustle of the big city and soon finds herself caring for Forrest in a way she never would have expected.

The film's biggest strength is also one of its main failings, and that's the setting. The incredibly rural setting of a Prohibition-era drama is something that is not seen very often, because the majority of them take place in the big cities (although a film like Sam Mendes' ROAD TO PERDITION is partially set in the boonies), and that's something that a director like Hillcoat and a writer like Cave would feel like they would want to immerse the viewer into that world, but we only catch glimpses. It seems like the setting is more incidental rather than a necessary part of the storytelling. Everyone in it is good with really three stand-out performances: Tom Hardy is excellent as the soft-spoken but deadly Forrest who acts as the patriarch for his brothers; Guy Pearce is amazing and chameleon-like as the needlessly sadistic and sweet-scented Rakes who is trying to be the city gent, but is too brutal and cruel to ever be accepted as such. Every scene of his drips with menace. Also standing out here is Dane Dehaan (wonderful in the brilliant little-seen gem CHRONICLE) as Cricket, the resident mechanical genius and hero-worshipping child whose vulnerability is extended beyond that of a cliche. LaBoeuf takes his time with his character in building it and turns in a very commendable performance in easliy his most complex role yet. The rest of the cast work best with what they have but what they have isn't much. Mia Wasikowska has a wonderful scene with LaBoeuf as he takes her out for a drive, but that's really the extent of her character as something for the young Jack to long for. Jason Clarke is the most short-changed of the Bondurants here, being portrayed as a drunk and a thug, but little else. Gary Oldman has little more than a cameo in this film, and from a completely subjective point of view, I wanted more because there was something there to really allow for him to have fun and cut loose like we had seen in years past. Sadly the one player here that is the most marginalized is Jessica Chastain. She's an actress that will undoubtedly have an Oscar in her hand before the decade is out, and she does some really good work here, but her character of Maggie is very much the weary and damaged madonna/whore for Forrest, and very little else.

Another real problem is the pacing of the film. It's not that it's uneven; it's that it's too fast. This film moves along at such a brisk pace that at its little over 100-minute runtime seems too brief for a film of this type. I felt like I was being rushed out of the theater rather than being invited in to experience something unusual and lyrical, like Hillcoat and Cave's THE PROPOSITION. That was a film that took the Western out of the "Old West" and placed it in Austrailia's Outback, and it invited the viewer to really soak in all the elements of the environment the film was set in, which were strange and wonderful and terrible. This is honestly the first time in a while where I felt that a longer runtime would have benefitted the film, particularly from a character standpoint.

LAWLESS, while being beautiful to look at and well-performed, is sadly lacking heart and soul that could have easily elevated this film to greater heights. But in all fairness, when LAWLESS works, it works really well, and that does happen slightly more often than not.

3/5 Stars.

Oscar season has officially begun with the arrival of "Lawless", the best movie of the year so far. The movie is based upon a 2008 novel "The Wettest County in the World", written by Matt Bondurant, who is the grandson and grand nephew of the characters depicted in the film. The film, set in prohibition-era Franklin County, Virginia, is an authentic and truthful depiction of life as they knew it in bootleg heavy, depression-era Virginia.

The story centers around the Bondurant brothers, Forrest (Tom Hardy), Howard (Jason Clarke) and Jack (Shia Lebeouf), Jack being the younger and more timid of the three. In fact, Forrest and Howard, can not at all be described as anything close to timid.

Prohibition is in place, yet moonshine is run back and forth from county line to county line without any trouble. There's an unwritten acceptance of a business that hasn't really caused any trouble. Yet, things are beginning to brew in Chicago with many now well known gangsters thriving, the government is cracking down. It is just a matter of time before that crack down reaches them in the hills of Virginia. So, unless the Bondurant's want trouble, they have to begin to pay the government for the pleasure of continuing to do business. That doesn't sit well with Forrest and Howard.

The movie, written by Nick Cave and directed by John Hillcoat is an absolute stunner. Not necessarily for the images depicted on screen, but for the quality of the film, given that Nick Cave has only written three screenplays since 1988. Twenty-four years and only two prior scripts and Nick Cave may just be one of the biggest hidden secrets in Hollywood. Known mostly for his music, but Cave has delivered a tight, can't take my eyes off the screen, Oscar night guarantee.

The authenticity of the film and the beauty of the cinematography is what film making is all about. The creators took us back in time nearly a century and never once do you question its validity and never once do you want to miss a single scene. The humor is perfect and the violence is harsh and realistic. You feel the tenseness and the unpredictable nature of what the film could possibly do at any given moment.

I'm surprised that it's already September and I've yet to see a film that made me mention the word Oscar. "Lawless" will be part of Oscar night. Screenplay, direction and performances by Guy Pierce, Shia Lebeouf, Jessica Chastain and Dark Knight's Tom Hardy are all going to be at least considerations. If you like great cinema, don't miss "Lawless". Although, this is also one of those movies that will have a nice long life on people's tongues and video.

I like the movie, but the writing isn't quite as sharp as I'd thought it could be.  I think the world has had enough of Shia LaBeouf by now, too, but if this somehow ends up being his last high-profile gig then at least he went out on a high note.  He would not have been among my first ten casting choices for this role, but I found his presence less annoying in "Lawless" than in most everything else I've seen him in.

But this movie belongs to Tom Hardy, hands down.  Anyone familiar with Hardy's body of work knows that he can deliver the goods ("Bronson", anyone?).  He has such a dynamic and commanding presence about him that you can't take your eyes off him.  When he's not onscreen you can't wait for him to come back.  He was the best thing about "The Dark Knight Rises".  In fact, he was the ONLY good thing about "The Dark Knight Rises".  He'll get more profile for that film than for many of his others, and that's unfortunate too considering how weak that material was.

Between "Bronson", "Lawless", and 2011's "Warrior" (and shame on you if you haven't watched all three of these), Hardy's place as one of his generation's best and most versatile screen actors is secured.

The other thing about "Lawless" I didn't care for was how a few songs seemed to get shoe-horned into the story when simple, subtle background score would have sufficed.  It was distracting.  But Nick Cave wrote a few of those and he gets paid more than just his screenwriter's salary if his songs make it into the film and onto the soundtrack, so there you go.  I noticed the same pattern in "The Proposition", another film Cave wrote and contributed songs for.  Cave co-wrote the score for "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford" and that music was quite good, so I'm not on an anti-Cave rant here.

"Lawless" is bloody and violent too, so leave the kids in the other room.  But it's a superior genre piece and worth watching.

And I have nothing against seeing a little female flesh now and again, but I thought Jessica Chastain's nude scene was gratuitous.  I certainly didn't DISlike it, but in my head I was screaming "Okay, apparently it is time for the obligatory ingenue nude scene.  Get it over with and let's move on."

I really enjoy the HBO series that sometimes drags a bit much, but this movie covers drama and action so well in just two hours. Three brothers from Virginia in 1931 earn all of their money from bootlegging. But of course, the mob and the local state officials want their cut as well. This leads to a bunch of killing. You know the drill here, but the cast somehow made this material seem fresh.

All of the actors are great. Tom Hardy (Mr. Bane himself) and Guy Pearce put on acting showcases here. Really good stuff. Heck, even Shia LaBeouf turned in his best performance of his career. I could actually stand him. Jessica Chastain holds her own with the guys and has a nude scene that I wasn't expecting, but no complaints.

There was bloody violence, humor and sex all wrapped up in a nicely flawed, but throughly enjoyable package. Like I said, nothing really new here, but if you enjoy gangster films there is much to appreciate in Lawless. It's one of my favorite movies of the year so far.

*Note* **There is actually more that goes with this review on my blog since I saw an advance screening of Lawless in the beginning of August and met the author of the book this movie is based on, Matt Bondurant. Matt's grandfather is Jack Bondurant (played by Shia LaBeouf) and Howard and Forrest were his granduncles. To read my full post on meeting Matt and getting to talk to him about how his family saga got turned into a movie, do a google search for The Muses Circle, click on Movie Reviews, and scroll down to Lawless.**

I absolutely have nothing negative to say about Lawless. Some critics have complained that while the acting was top notch, the story itself was derivative. Are there elements of the plot that we've seen in other films before? Yes. But does is straight up copy another movie? No. But let's get it straight. The point of Lawless was never to give us something we've completely never seen before. Come on, this is not the Matrix. Hillcoat's vision was to give us a twist on the gangster genre, give us something a little less conventional. So while there were elements that felt familiar, there were also scenes that you just didn't expect; scenes that perhaps you expected to go one way, but ended up playing out completely different. I have a couple scenes in mind but I don't want to spoil anything.

In my opinion, Nick Cave did a great job with the script and the soundtrack. I liked Jack's bits of narration throughout the film. The movie was well paced-- my mind never wandered nor did I feel bored. So if some of you are hesitating to see Lawless because you're worried that the action or scenes of violence are far and wide between, you have nothing to worry about. Cave is more known as a song writer and composer then he is for writing scripts. So I had a feeling the soundtrack was going to be interesting. It was a breath of fresh air. Instead of going with the traditional sound of straight up blue grass, country music (remember this movie is part western, part gangsteresque), he somehow mixed in some new with some old.

Now to the outstanding cast of Lawless. You may disagree with everything I've said so far, but one thing that cannot be denied is the amazing acting in this film, even for those who have less screen time. I'll be the first to admit I am not a Shia LaBeouf fan. Walking into this movie, I thought I was going to have to just ignore him and pray the other actors would be able to carry him. While I still won't be the first person lined up to see his next movie, I have to give credit where credit is due: Shia LaBeouf can act. From his southern drawl to his convincing performance as a boy that still hasn't quite transitioned into manhood, I think he did a great job playing Jack Bondurant.

Jason Clarke who portrays the eldest brother in the Bondurant clan Howard, was a bit overshadowed by other performances, but I won't soon forget those eyes. They are eyes that have seen things that no man should ever have the burden of seeing and it's no surprise why he drowns himself in moonshine. The way Clarke was able to sometimes appear "tuned out" out was impressive.

Gary Oldman as gangster Floyd Banner was electrifying, but shorter then expected. It's one of those cases where Hollywood uses an actor's name to draw people into the film, but they aren't actually in the majority of it.

Jessica Chastain is a great actress so I wasn't surprised by her solid, strong female performance as Maggie. I loved how she could walk into a room and instantly remind the rough-around-the-edges Bondurant boys of their manners in the presence of a lady. The other lady in the movie, Mia Wasikowska, who plays Bertha (Jack's love interest) was as perfect as always. She is young but can hang with the heavyweights as she has proven in previous performances in Jane Eyre and Albert Nobbs.

If you are looking for a villain you will hate as much as the characters do in the film, then you will love Guy Pearce's spin on Special Deputy Rake. Pearce is probably one of the most underrated but brilliant actors around and I am glad that the part went to him since Rake as a character is quite interesting. He's from the city, wears perfume, appears to look the part of a gentlemen but we soon realize underneath the nice clothes, coifed hair, and girly smell, there's something not quite...right. Like the gloves he wears and the naked African American girl in his room that he has sitting on newspapers on top of his bed. Yeah...check it out, you will see what I mean.

I think the character that I least expected to connect with was Cricket and the credit has to go to Dane DeHaan. I kept thinking he was the younger version of Leonardo DeCaprio and I don't know why but his performance in Lawless reminded me of DeCaprio as Arnie in What's Eating Gilbert Grape. The physical likeness of the two is uncanny. I can't wait to see DeHaan evolve over time.

Okay, so I had to save the best for last. I promise to keep my praise of this next actor as short as possible since there are really no words that can fully describe his performance. You just need to see it. Tom Hardy was compelling as Forrest Bondurant, the middle brother and the head of the family. I read somewhere that the director John Hillcoat was "awestruck" by Hardy's performance. I think I was awestruck when I saw Hardy as Bane in The Dark Knight Rises, but let me say this: I don't need any more proof, he is a phenomenal actor. Any actor that can wear a Mr. Rogers' cardigan and remain sexy, masculine, and still be the baddest dude on screen is just amazing. Hardy always makes Forrest appear relaxed, yet intense. His mannerisms such as the way he walks, talks is a pleasure to watch. Forrest is the glue that keeps everything in his world together and I am not just talking about his importance as the businessman in the family. Forrest has to keep a watchful eye on his older brother Howard who can fly off the handle in a second, who can at times appear tuned out and sometimes wonder if it is all from the moonshine or from the horrors he saw at war. Then on the other end is young Jack, his baby brother that he knows isn't quite cut out for the lifestyle but knowing and trying to convince the youngest in the Bondurant family are two different beasts. I'm not saying Forrest couldn't have been played by another actor, but Tom Hardy brought something special to the character that could never be replicated.

I think John Hillcoat has succeeded in his goal. He has given us a western/gangster flick that feels familiar yet still maintains its freshness. If you're looking for a film with a solid story, great acting, with nicely paced bursts of violence, look no further. Lawless has arrived. But let us not give all the credit to Hollywood for there would be no movie without Matt Bondurant and his novelization of his grandfather and granduncle's legend sized escapades. I read somewhere that Matt Bondurant's one regret was that he never spent enough time with his grandfather as so often happens with young people. That maybe writing Wettest County in the World was his way to honor the memory of the man he knew and the man he wished he had had the time to get to know. Don't worry, Matt. Grandpa Jack would be proud.

Australian director John Hillcoat brings many of his countrymen with him to film this fact based novel ("The Wettest County in the World") by Matt Bondurant.  Bondurant's grandfather Jack played here by Shia LaBeouf is the hothead youngest brother of a clan of Prohibition era bootleggers in Virginia.  They make a decent living until a crooked politician vows to eliminate all the small sellers.  He brings in a law enforcement officer from Chicago named Charley Rakes (Guy Pearce).

Rakes is no ordinary federal cop.  A popinjay smelling of perfume with slicked back hair and lavender gloves he stands out like a T-Rex in the hills of southeastern Virginia.  His appearance contradicts his viciousness as the legal hired gun.  While all the local citizenry fall in line, the Bondurants are the exception.  Oldest brother Forrest (Tom Hardy) and Howard (Jason Clarke) are hulking men who essentially want to be left alone.  Alas, they won't be.

As he did in "The Proposition" (2005) and 2009's "The Road," Hillcoat doesn't shy away from violence, and aside from a couple instances, it comes with viciousness and realism.  The film does slip occasionally, usually when Jack does something really stupid knowing of their situation.  Even with his youth, his foolishness seemed calculated to get LaBeouf and Mia Wasikowska, as Jack's girlfriend, more screen time.  On the whole the film gives an entertaining vision of gnarly Prohibition era Americana.

This is one hell of a gritty movie, and looks very realistic to the period portrayed. It's not a fun, feelgood story though. It's a tale of bootleggers during Prohibition so prepare yourself for violence and blood. The cast is fantastic with outstanding performances by Jessica Chastain, the amazing and versatile Tom Hardy, Guy Pearce as a nasty lawman, and a surprisingly deep and touching performance by Shia LaBeouf. I would say this is his best performance to date, Oscar-worthy even. I give it four stars, not five, due to the dark nature of the story which at times was hard to watch. If you want a realistic film about moonshiners from the back country, this is it. If you want superb acting, this is it. If you want a comfy night with a feelgood movie and some popcorn, this definitely isn't it. It's exciting, scary and suspenseful but very violent, so pick wisely. And thanks to the great actors for setting the mood well.

As one who, over many decades, has viewed too many movies to count, I was amazed at how many scenes in the movie seemed really surprising  and effective in a very original way.  Rich in period and location atmosphere, its well acted roster of characters struck me as fascinating and engaging.  Standouts were the performances by Tom Hardy, Jessica Chastain, and Shia LaBoeuf.  Hardy seems to achieve fabulous results with every part he is given.  This is the second time LaBoeuf has done such strong, committed acting that my original tendency to dismiss him as a lightweight has been dispelled.  (The first of these roles was his explosive turn in the Brad Pitt scorcher, "Fury'.)  Guy Pearce (always an actor to watch), stylishly portrays a wildly twisted, villainous individual who is so over-the-top that he occasionally stretches credibility; however, the characterization is a bit like a dazzling magic act. One is too transfixed by the sheer theatricality of it to react critically.  This is a dark, often violent film, unfolding in striking locations, with a climactic battle that, although somewhat predictable, packs a mighty punch.  I might have wished that the Gary Oldman part in the story had not been simply cut short after a few key scenes, but I am, nevertheless, inclined to give this absorbing drama a hearty recommendation.

There's a lot of talent on display here, but it's hard not to feel that the movie ought to have been a little better than it turned out to be.  The story is based on a novel written by Matt Bondurant about events in Franklin County, Virginia at the time of Prohibition, and it recounts how three Bondurant brothers and their helpers managed -- sort of heroically, I suppose -- to supply the surrounding countryside with moonshine while corrupt law-enforcement agents (some Federal ones) tried to bring down the operation when the brothers refuse to cut them in on the action.  It's really a Robin Hood kind of story, for the brothers are lawless, to be sure, but the law -- in the shape of Special Deputy Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce) -- is even more lawless, if possible, and so there's no one for the audience to root for but the outlaws.  It's on one level a story of escalating confrontations, ending with a climactic gun battle at a blockade at a covered bridge (very well choreographed), and the director, John Hillcoat, and screenwriter Nick Cave, give the escalating action the rhythm of an old ballad, with images of wooded pastoral scenes and picturesque rustic dwellings interspersed with scenes of very bloody violence that would be perhaps enough to put at least some viewers off.  Adding to the ballad-like quality is the use of old mountain songs that move us along through narrative transitions, written and performed in the manner of the period, with the voices of Emmylou Harris and Ralph Stanley well deployed.  The larger world outside Franklin County is hinted at  -- Forrest Bondurant (Tom Hardy), the oldest brother, made it through World War 1, and there are allusions to the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl -- but these circumstances are only touched on.

The weakness of the movie might be in the handling of the characters.  Forrest is almost deliberately inarticulate, a slow-moving, bulky man with a cold-blooded streak when he's attacked.  Hardy plays him compellingly, but he's more a physical presence than anything else.  Jason Clarke is Howard Bondurant, the middle brother, and he isn't really characterized at all.  The main focus is on Jack Bondurant (Shia LaBeouf), as he develops from a teenager who wants to be in on the action and yet cannot summon up the violence needed to survive.  Jack's narration at times in the story contributes to the ballad atmosphere, but for me LaBeouf isn't really a compelling enough presence for us to find him very interesting.  The fact that he's in the frame with Hardy, Gary Oldman, and Guy Pearce is challenging.  Oldman has a cameo as Floyd Banner, another local criminal who has an uneasy relationship with the Bondurants for much of the movie, and he carries it off with characteristic panache.  Pearce's role as a Special Deputy is a large one, and the character is conceived flamboyantly, and Pearce carries it off in great style -- as despicable a movie villain as you'll see, and to an extent, he dominates the movie.  Jessica Chastain and Mia Wasikowska are the women the Bondurants are interested in, and both do well, though Wasikowska's role is somewhat stereotyped.  I had just seen Tom Hardy in "The Drop," and I liked that movie better.  This one is a different genre, of course, and it's good to look at but lacking something at the center.

I can't say enough about this film but I will try:  outstanding cast with many of my favorites - Gary Oldman, Guy Pearce, Mia Wasikowska and the spectacular Tom Hardy who is just incredible.  Also, spectacular cinematography, unbelievable soundtrack with Emmy Lou Harris on it as a bonus, excellent screenplay.  I will probably purchase this film to view over and over.  Highly recommend, particular for Tom Hardy fans.

This is the story of three brothers, two romances, and moonshine business during Prohibition, with incredibly interesting work of a stellar ensemble cast. Sometimes I really get ticked off at Hollywood. This could've been an outstanding film, but alas, artistry was snuffed for formula. But, hark, there is hope! Three key artistic elements came together to save this film from formulaic obscurity. (1) The intense polarization of Tom Hardy's protagonist/hero character and Guy Pearce's antagonist/villain character. Hardy is gravitas incarnate on screen. His backwoods protagonist Forrest is understandably at odds with Pearce's sociopathic city-slicker Charley Rakes. We see Rakes from the Bondurants perspective: a very real danger from the outside who threatens their livelihood. There is absolutely zero compromise between these two characters. (2) The film should have been longer in order to accommodate richer romantic subplots between the Jessica Chastain/Tom Hardy characters and LaBeouf/Wasikowska characters. Surface criticism says these characters are forced, but they really add depth and humanism to the brutal world in which they exist. (3) The soundtrack fits in wonderfully and feels authentic to the period. This film didn't blow me away, but it should have.

Lawless is the true story of the infamous Bondurant Brothers: bootlegging siblings who made a run for the American Dream in Prohibition-era Virginia. In this epic gangster tale, inspired by true- life tales of author Matt Bondurant's family in his novel "The Wettest County in the World", the loyalty of the three brothers Jack, Forrest and Howard Bondurant, who sold moonshine in Franklin County, Virginia, during Prohibition in the United States.

Grim, bloody, and utterly flawed, Lawless doesn't quite achieve the epic status it strains for, but it's too beautifully filmed and powerfully acted to dismiss. It had great potential, but due to a poor storytelling technique that causes the film to be rather dull, we merely end up with a film that just looks good. But still,this Prohibition-era crime drama boasts bravura performances, unforgettable characters, moments of shocking violence, and enough in-your-face entertainment that features a unique villain and several great supporting actors such as sublimely evil performances by Gary Oldman as a murderous rival and Guy Pearce as a government agent. As for Jessica Chastain, her performance in this film is commendable enough that her fans would surely enjoy. Between sporadic bursts of very intense violence, there are often drafty, drowsy scenes that struggle to justify their relevance. Overall, it certainly had its moments yet lacks the tension of a real classic.

This film has been out for a couple of years, but by reading this review I hope readers who missed it will check it out, because "Lawless" is a movie on par with "Wiseguys", "Shutter Island" or "Road To Perdition" as one of the best historically based movies of all time.  That is no exaggeration.
  "Lawless" is the true tale of a family of brothers, the Bondurants, who, during Prohibition in the early 1920's, ran a very lucrative moonshine operation out of a remote Virginia county.  That is, until a very corrupt and evil lawman played by the great Guy Pearce shows up and decides to take a cut of the pie.  Unfortunately the Bondurants aren't the sharing type and are not easily bullied.
  The story is gripping, violent and even painful at times, especially in the tit-for-tat brutality that takes place between Pearce and the brothers.  Shia Labeuf plays youngest brother Jack, but in this movie is not very believable, at least in my view.  I don't care for him or his antics off screen.  However, the movie is also starring the great Tom Hardy, the British actor who is taking America by storm, with an amazing depth, ability to change accents from his native British to hillbilly and in "The Drop", to Brooklyn-ese effortlessly.  As Forrest Bondurant, the leader of the brothers, he is spellbinding - soft spoken but, when the need arises, a vicious monster that idiots who cross him soon find out.  Gary Oldham plays a bit part, and that's too bad because he's great in the few scenes he's in.
  Hardy could and should have received an Oscar for his part, and one hopes he will get it after his outstanding performance in "The Drop".  "Lawless" will be a classic tale of corruption and family loyalty.  Don't miss out.

Entertaining and well acted 1930's era film showcasing the true story of a trio of moonshining brothers in rural Virginia. Starring Shia LaBeouf, Tom Hardy, Guy Pearce and Jason Clarke, and backed by a superb cast of well drawn and captivating characters, "Lawless" is both a straight crime story with folk hero overtones and a poignant look at familial loyalty and approval in an era when Prohibition encouraged the profusion of backwoods moonshine stills.

Lawless has plenty of opportunities to become violent for its own sake, but the story of how the three brothers deal with threats to their family business always takes precedence.  Because familial dynamics are paramount, Jack's (LaBeouf) clumsy attempts to emulate his nearly mythical older brother Forrest (Hardy) are allowed to organically develop.  The inevitability of the brothers' criminal life trajectory and the ending are seemingly at counterpoint, but when the ending comes we're both relieved and satisfied.

A few notes about the acting.  Tom Hardy is wonderful as the understated and hulking older brother Forrest, while LaBeouf is simply a treasure in his role as the younger brother Jack.  His ability to convey anguish and love, and finally anger result in his best acting performance yet.

Directed by John Hillcoat from a book by Matt Bondurant (Grandchild of the film's Jack).  Well crafted, emotionally involving, and a brutal but loving insight into this proud family.

Amidst the chaos and confusion that followed the ratification of the 18th amendment in 1919, emerged a group of outlaw entrepreneurs aiming to taking full advantage of the dry times.  Among this group came the Bondurant brothers, Forrest (Tom hardy), Howard (Jason Clarke), Jack (Shia LaBeouf), and their tenacious quest for cash by means of bootlegging moonshine as portrayed in the film Lawless. While some viewers may frown upon the outlandish amount of violence that ensues throughout the movie, I commend director John Hillcoat on his ability to recreate the troubles and triumphs of the risky trade in a sentimental fashion, so compelling, that I found myself both furious and hurt at times.
 The film itself follows loosely the novel The Wettest County in the World, centered on the small town of Franklin, Virginia. Stunning views of the southern countryside seen through a somewhat sepia-like filter give a great sense of setting to the story.  A banjo-infused country western soundtrack also reflects the slow paced lifestyle of the town.  In contrast to that, The Bonderant brothers are almost always hard at work in a world of their own.
 In terms of the actors ability to take on the persona of the Bondurants, all three brothers certainly possess their own unique rendition on the southern twang.  Tom Hardy, the brains of the group, utilizes a more gravelly voice almost as if every sound that comes out of his mouth might be his last.  Jason Clarke, the drunken feisty one, remains rather quiet, though never afraid to lash out and bark at his opposition.  Finally, we have Shia LaBeouf as Jack Bondurant.  Unlike the other two brothers, Jack lacks a lot of the confidence needed to keep the Bondurants reputation in tact.  LaBeouf does a phenomenal job of playing the role of a brother far too concerned with what others think of him in the town. Labeoufs shaky and goofy voice says it all.
 As the film moves on, foes are introduced, the worst of which being special agent Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce), summoned from the city of Chicago to deal with the widespread bootlegging.  Faced with the threat of halting all operations and transactions, the brothers quickly realize the severity of the situation.  Shia LaBeouf begins to grow as a character.  LaBeoufs initial looks of uncertainty are transformed into that of utter confidence.  Along with this maturity comes Jacks ability to swoon the ladies, giving this action/drama film a slight love story twist.
 All in all, John Hillcoats vision for Lawless was far from disappointing.  Everything from the diversity of individuals in the town and their clothing to the engineering of the stills used to make moonshine was on point.  The mannerisms of the brothers echo their merciless attitudes towards the authorities.  Hillcoat gives viewers no choice but to empathize with the Bondurants and their anti-hero attributes. Whatever I've seen in my past concerning moonshine running has been on the lighter side. This film takes you in the total opposite direction.

Here's the scoop. Set in depression era Franklin County, Virginia, this story involves the 3 Bondurant brothers who make and run moonshine. A heavy weight deputy from Chicago (Guy Pearce) arrives and is determined to shut them down. Things get out of hand.

This is an uber violent film. All manner of grievous bodily harm ensues. Shootings, beatings and throat cuttings make up most of it. The older brothers (Tom Hardy, Jason Clarke) know their business, while the younger brother (Shia LaBouf) wants to prove himself worthy of equal billing. He's also courting the local preacher's daughter. Guy Pearce is particularly sleazy. There have been several violent bad guys in film history that showed shades of homosexuality. Somehow it makes them all the scarier. That's Pearce. He's referred to as a "Nancy boy." And he goes way out of his way to be as violent as possible.

The performances are good. Especially Tom Hardy. I'm no Shia LaBouf fan but he IS getting better. Gary Oldman's role is too small as is Mia Wasikowska's. But Jessica Chastain looks delicious and chews her role up just fine. I like the look of the film. Great attention is paid to period detail. I also liked the music though some of it tried, unsuccessfully, to make things lighter. This is too heavy for that. It's shot really well and the directing is a bit odd. Difficult to explain but it looks as though director Hillcoat always had the camera in some spot that was counter intuitive to where I thought it would be. But I DID like it.

Set during the Prohibition Era in 1931, LAWLESS traces the fortunes of the three Bondicant brothers - Forrest (Tom Hardy), the brains, Howard (Jason Clarke), the heavy, and Jack (Shia LaBoeuf), the weakest of the trio, as they run their bootlegging business in a rural part of Franklin County, West Virginia.  Theirs is a risky business; not only do they have to worry about rival syndicates, notably that led by Floyd Banner (Gary Oldman), but they are continually harassed by an over-zealous deputy Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce), who is determined to eradicate them at all costs.  John Hillcoat's film explores the tempestuous relationship between the brothers; although perpetually denigrating Jack as the "runt" of the family, the other two always stand up for him, especially when he gets into trouble.  Likewise Jack does his best to maintain the bootlegging business, even if it means making an audacious trip to sell illicit hooch to Flord Banner, accompanied by the disabled Cricket Pate (Dane DeHaan).  The film establishes a convincing sense of period, a time when bootleggers either killed or were killed as they strove to maintain their supremacy in an overcrowded market.  Dismissed as "hicks," because of their rural origins, the Bondicoats turn out to be formidable adversaries, even though Forrest tends to believe a little too much in his (self-constructed) legend about the family's indestructibility.  The film is extremely violent, containing at least two stomach-churning sequences, but this is necessary to the depiction of a dog-eat-dog world in which everyone is out for themselves.  The only jarring note in an otherwise tautly plotted thriller is Guy Pearce's pantomime villain: with his immaculate suits and perpetually curled lip, he seems to have wandered in from a Victorian melodrama rather than an early Thirties gangster movie.  We feel that his demise at the end is richly deserved, as Jack finally overcomes his squeamishness about shooting enemies and mortally wounds the deputy.  Howard completes the coup de grace by stabbing Rakes in the back.

I remember seeing the preview for "Lawless" while preparing to watch another movie. I instantly wanted to see it. Yet, the opportunity passed, and I wasn't ready to buy the DVD until I was certain I would like the movie. Although I was born in the late 1960s, my father was born in 1920. He often said he bootlegged himself to help the family survive as his father was a poor farm laborer. There were three brothers in the movie and my father had two brothers. Forrest Bondurant reminds me so much of my father in his latter years, it's not funny.

Enough of that. On to the movie. Nick Cave nailed the spirit of the book and the music of the time. It was as if we were watching the real events unfold in person instead of on a cable network. I inherited my love of good stories and movies from my father. There was an even distribution of action throughout, and the scene where Forrest's throat is cut was violent, bloody, and frighteningly realistic. How Forrest Bondurant survived that, I will never know. I loved the unfolding romances between Forrest and Maggie. Their scenes were brilliant. Tom Hardy brought the character to life in a way no other actor could have imagined. His Virginian accent was flawless. He was a scene stealer. It was as if he was born to portray Forrest. I was less interested in the romance of Jack and Bertha. Perhaps it was due to the fact that Tom Hardy and Jessica Chastain overshadowed Shia LaBeouf and Mia Wasikowska. The chemistry between Mr. Hardy and Ms. Chastain was unbelievable. Although it was Jack's story, more or less, one cannot deny that Forrest and Howard were larger than life, as were the actors who portrayed them. I found myself cheering for the moonshiners, the supposed 'bad' guys and jeering the law, the supposed 'good' guys.

Nick Cave, who also scored the music for "West Of Memphis," did so with "Lawless" as well. He captured the soul of music in those days, and the soundtrack is amazing. If anyone can make it through listening to Ralph Stanley without tearing up during Cricket Pate's funeral, has little heart. At the end, Mr. Stanley sang another bittersweet song that reminded me so much of my father, I cried the first time I heard it. See, in the movie, the brothers fight, but have each others' backs. That makes me think of my father and his two brothers. They fought like wild cats, but when one was threatened, they would all throw in the fight. In all, it was superb and I would give my recommendations. If nothing else, Tom Hardy's performance alone is enough to have this movie in one's collection.

Some years ago director John Hillcoat and screenwriter Nick Cave collaborated on a film called "The Proposition" set during Australia's colonial period that was definitely informed by Sergio Leone, Sam Peckinpah, and Clint Eastwood but had enough original flourishes to stand as a true original.  "Lawless" is cut from the same mold except the setting is Prohibition era Franklin County, Virginia.  Bootleg whiskey for generations was the county's primary industry and there was a gentleman's agreement between the manufacturers of moonshine and law enforcement that kept the business thriving.  Where there is a buck to be made, however, there are outsiders who want a piece of the action and they come in the form of a Chicago gangster(Gary Oldman) and a sadistic U.S. attorney(Guy Pearce).  The film focuses on the Bondurant family whose motto is "We control fear.  Fear doesn't control us".  The oldest brother Forrest (Tom Hardy) is bloodied but unbowed and will protect the family interests at all costs.  As in "The Proposition" Hillcoat doesn't shy away from the violence that's a byproduct of these turf wars.  You get a real sense of time and place with exquisite period art direction.  Cave is also the music arranger and provides a score that evokes Appalachia.  The standout performances here would probably be Hardy and Pearce.  Not for the squeamish but an accurate history.

A crime drama "Lawless" (2012) has everything that would make a great picture: talented players, moody photography, nice soundtrack music, etc. The only thing it doesn't have is a screenplay, one of the most neglected departments in making a movie.

Set in the Depression-era Virginia, "Lawless" chronicles the lives of the Bondurant brothers - Forrest (Tom Hardy), Howard (Jason Clarke) and Jack Bondurant (Shia LaBeouf), running a moonshine business in Franklin County. With the arrival of corrupt Special Deputy Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce), their business becomes more difficult, but the brothers will not give in to pressure to bribe.

Unlike Australian-born director John Hillcoat's previous work, a dark, post-apocalyptic tale "The Road," "Lawless" attempts to be a serious artistic work that also entertains. The result is a mixed bag. While the visuals are always attractive, the film does not know where it really wants to go, with flat characters whose fates we do not care much. The romantic subplot involving Mia Wasikowska's characters is forgettable. Jack Bondurant's transformation is not really convincing.

"Lawless" is just another example of how a story based on real-life figures could have been better. (And if you are a Gary Oldman fan like me, remember that his role is a small one, though he does a perfect job.)

This is an amazing account of history we don't really know about.  Especially in California, as we often think of southern culture as one size fits all, and neglect rural southern mountain culture, which this movie showcases.

This story revolves around a family of three brothers making hootch in their illegal still during Prohibition.  They are in a county where this is common and draws the attention of the government who tries to shut them all down.  The action is fast-paced and amazingly well-done.  Jessica Chastain is perfect as "Maggie", the woman who comes to work at their bar/gas station.  The attraction between Maggie and Forrest is quiet, intense and played with subtlety.  If somewhat graphic violence doesn't bother you, I'd say this is one of the best movies in years.  I highly recommend "Lawless"!

The opening scenes of "Lawless," John Hillcoat's fascinating 2012 work, are so intense they create anticipation the film does not live up to. Tom Hardy plays brother Forrest Bondurant, the formidable protector of a backwoods Virginia moonshine operation during the Prohibition. He has a face-off with a new sheriff of sorts, the preening Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce) who has arrived by way of Chicago to collect toll. Hardy's stare is so intense it practically cracks the camera lens. After barely a pronounced word and the twitch of a brow, you know instantly his savage code is not to be underestimated. It's a spellbinding moment the film rarely matches. There's a great movie here, a sort of combination of Miller's Crossing [HD] and Winter's Bone, but somewhere on the muddy back roads it becomes lost in box office ambition. Based on the true story of the Bondurants, with a screenplay adapted by Nick Cave from Matt Bondurant's memoir The Wettest County in the World: A Novel Based on a True Story, filmmakers cast Shia LaBeouf as the youngest brother -- the runt of the litter -- and primarily focus on his attempts to live the code while courting the preacher's daughter. Such plot developments are as old as James Cagney's socks. LaBeouf is an acquired taste anyway, possessing boyish looks without the slightest menace. Hardy's presence, not to mention Jason Clarke as the fearless older brother Howard, completely swallow LaBeouf's sniveling portrayal. There's a primitive society here (check out the classic documentary Harlan County, U.S.A. (The Criterion Collection)), and Hardy and Clarke capture the palpable nature of such blood cults. You need fingernail dirt, and LaBeouf has the presence of a kid folding jeans at The Gap. By way of Australia, Hillcoat has sparked an interesting career with The Proposition and The Road. "Lawless" is a step back, though shows signs of considerable post-production tinkering. One suspects the film clocked at three-plus hours and Hillcoat had to whittle down to two. There's a musical montage that shows the Bondurants rolling in moonshine money while Pearce's Rakes destroys neighboring stills dotting the Virginia mountains. It's the moment the film unravels. "Lawless" introduces two fascinating characters, including Maggie Beauford, a dame with a past (Jessica Chastain), and gangster Floyd Banner (Gary Oldman), but both are practically forgotten. Chastain especially deserves screen time, working the bar at the Bondurants' rural enterprise and capturing the wary eye of Forrest. There's an unforgettable scene when Chastain, sans clothes, slowly pats down a darkened hallway to his bed, ranking as one of the most haunting snapshots in recent memory. It's the type of image Jean Cocteau would admire (Beauty and The Beast (The Criterion Collection)). Such moments in "Lawless" abound. It's a beautiful film, with the extraordinary cinematography of Benoit Delhomme, on-location filming in rural Georgia and brooding set designs creating a lamentable atmosphere. But the plot flow is too fragmented. You know there's going to be a showdown between Forrest and Sheriff Rakes, and they indeed meet next to a covered bridge surrounded by men toting rusty shotguns. By this point, the film has entirely lost its momentum, and it stumbles to an abrupt ending lacking the poetry Hillcoat was hoping for. Prior to "Lawless," I had only seen Hardy in a few blockbuster epics (Inception). His performance is a revelation, possessing the presence of mountains. It's a bitter sin we are forced to endure LaBeouf's preening. There's an interesting supporting character, a local handicapped youth named Cricket. Played by relative unknown Dane DeHaan, it's a striking portrait of tragedy. Wouldn't it have been interesting to switch DeHaan and LaBeouf? I'm just not convinced LaBeouf can evolve into the kind of leading man of action "Lawless" attempts to force-feed us. And when you have Hardy, Clarke, Chastain and Oldman standing in the background with the film's running time slowly ticking away, you know a great opportunity has been lost.

So I recently got around to watching Lawless for the first time and I must admit I was pretty impressed. Going in I wasn't really sure what to expect. I don't remember seeing any trailers leading up to its release and I ultimately had no clue what it was about. All I really knew was that Shia LaBeouf was in it. While the film probably won't find its way into my list of favorites, it's hard not to appreciate just how good it actually is.

Based on a true story, what isn't these days, Lawless follows the lives of the three Bondurant brothers during the prohibition era. Forrest (Tom Hardy), Howard (Jason Clarke), and Jack (LaBeouf) run a moonshine business and while these three actors may not look similar in appearance, their chemistry on screen more than makes up for it. Forrest is the oldest, and possibly the wisest, Howard is a hothead, and Jack is pretty much the runt of the group who lacks the fearlessness that his brothers have. The movie lets you know this from the get-go as a younger Jack is unable to pull the trigger on a pig on his dad's farm.

Everything seems to be going ok for the three brothers until Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce) comes along. Charlie is a deputy from Chicago who was sent to crack down on the bootlegging currently going on in Franklin County, Virginia. Even though I hated his character with a passion Pearce did a phenomenal job at bringing this character to life, which seems to be a common theme among the entire cast.

As I watched the film part of me felt that Jack was supposed to be the main character. He was the one you were supposed to care about the most, but I found it hard to do that when Tom Hardy comes through and just dominates his performance as Forrest. I don't remember the last time I've seen an actor get so into his character. Off the top of my head I can only think of two: Heath Ledger in The Dark Knight and Joseph Gordon-Levitt in 50/50. As I watched the film on the couch I truly felt intimidated by Forrest. Here was a man who did not give a single damn. He didn't do what he did because he wanted to, he does it out of necessity. Out of his sheer will to live. Hardy's character doesn't necessarily have a lot of dialogue, but sometimes it's his silence or his facial expressions that say more than any dialogue ever could.

Some minor roles include Maggie (Jessica Chastain), Bertha Minnix (Mia Wasikowska), Cricket (Dane DeHaan), and Floyd Banner (Gary Oldman). Just like the main cast these supporting actors give outstanding performances. Maggie is a former dancer from Chicago who wanted to get away from the city life. She winds up being the waitress at the Bondurant gas station and also, later on, Forrest's love interest. Bertha is a young Amish woman who Jack is obviously attracted to. At first I thought that her role felt forced and insignificant, but it later proves to be more important than I initially thought. Cricket is a friend of Bondurant brothers who helps with their moonshine business. And Floyd Banner is a mobster who later becomes an ally to Jack. As previously stated, each of these actors brought their A-game. However, it would be criminal of me if I didn't give a little bit of recognition to Gary Oldman. The man has maybe a total of 20 lines throughout the entire movie, but, just like Hardy, he put it all on the table. He made himself Floyd Banner and he's just a joy to watch.

As a whole I felt the story was solid. The only part that really annoyed me was that they had a main character (Jack) who is unable to do what needs to be done until the situation gets as bad as it could possibly get. I don't know about anyone else, but to me that whole scenario is extremely overdone in movies like this. It says it's based on a true story, but there was obviously some tweaks made to make it a better cinematic experience. There were a few scenes that felt slightly unnecessary, but all in all everything flowed together really well and was presented by some nearly flawless camera work. The cherry on top? Well that would have to be the fantastic score produced by Nick Cave and Warren Ellis. It has that classic Country-Western vibe without feeling overwhelming and there were a few times during the darker scenes where I felt chills rush down my spine.

Overall Score: 8/10 - Considering I had little to no knowledge about this movie going in I have to admit that the final result was more than satisfying. The story may not be perfect, but it's held together by some good pacing, a strong cast, a great score, and some phenomenal acting. If you're into gangster-esque films and you have two hours to kill I definitely recommend giving this this a shot.

I live in West Virginia on the border with Kentucky and have had work-related reasons to visit Franklin County.  Much of it is still little different from its appearance and portrayal in the first-rate film Lawless.

As presented in Lawless, Franklin County might be characterized as "Bloody Franklin," roughly comparable to Harlan County or "Bloody Harlan," the setting for never-ending, violent conflict between coal miners on their way to early graves from Black Lung and gun thugs aided and abetted by corrupt officials working for Big Coal.  Lawless, however, takes a different, though equally ugly and violent tack, focusing on the production and distribution of bootleg whiskey.

Lawless romanticizes the lives and times of bootleggers in unashamed fashion, presenting them as tough-as-a-nickel-steak  heroes with a good deal of homespun integrity.  By contrast, their most conspicuous adversaries are caricatures of legally sanctioned viciousness and in-your-face arrogance, outsiders whose pomade can't cover their lack of character, something shared only by real men who have done what they have to in making their way in a hostile world.

That said, how does the viewer see Lawless as something with more gravity than backwoods, slack-jawed campiness?  One way is to take Lawless seriously as an allegory for life in the Appalachian U.S.  There, in rural West Virginia, Pennsylvania, and Kentucky, the contrast between right and wrong, good and bad, decent and decadent are as clear cut, plain to see, and fraught with peril as in a mainland China forced labor camp.  In a lot of places in our world, subtlety, nuance, shades of gray, and understatement are artificial contrivances that misrepresent rather than clarify.  Contrary to aesthetically mandated conventional wisdom, some stories really do have only one side.  If you're afflicted with a really powerful aversion to this accurately simplified view of much of the world, you won't like Lawless any more than you'd like, say, John Sayles' movie Matewan or the Norwegian film The King of Devil's Island.  You'll find it just too easy to make hard and fast moral judgments.

Lawless, however, is not devoid of artful and well-wrought irony.  The good guys are the law breakers, trying to get by in a hard place during the hardest of times.  With or without free booze, the local cops are sympathetic to their mountain-bred brethren and they rein in the worst excesses of their nominal allies sent in from the outside.  The lead character, played by Shia LeBouf, is not the feckless loose cannon that first appearances might lead us to expect him to be.  Jessica Chastain really is looking for peace and quiet, a reprieve from the chaos, grime, and random cruelty of city life.  Tom Hardy's fanciful run in with natural causes proves to be more of a challenge than knives and bullets that draw blood in anger.

LeBouf does a good job of maintaining his unlikely clean-cut boyishness throughout the film, but it would be good to know more about him.  Mia Waiskowska inserts a believable streak of independence and a good deal of cultural contrast into her Amish-like character as Lebouf's love interest, though LeBouf's peaceable dinner with her family may be a bit far-fetched.  Tom Hardy is always likable, though he plays his character so low-key that he could serve as a stand-in for Mumbles, one of Hardy's friends in the black comedy Rock'n'Rolla.  Guy Pearce does a superb job as official Hooveresque evil personified.

Lawless is by no means a perfect film, but it's a lot of fun with excitement and intensity to spare.  I liked it, and I'll watch it again.  Blood flows freely in this violent world, evoking the dark, violent, and, yes, lawless themes that pervade this part of our planet.

Australian John Hillcoat is without a doubt one of the most fascinating filmmakers working today, an heir to a style of filmmaking that not only seems dead now, but long so. His movies are beauties to behold, they are character driven, action filed and deal with themes of displaced men and time. His new movie, Lawless, is no exception, to say it fails to reach the same heights as his two previous pictures is not a criticism so much as an observation, it's not as powerful as the highly regarded stark western the Proposition nor is it as deeply moving as his underrated adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's the Road. With a recent output like that, it would be tough to continue or equal it, yet Lawless is still a sensational motion picture, not just one of the year's very best, but a strong identifiable work that will be appreciated for a long time to come.
 Working from a screenplay by musician Nick Cave, who also wrote the excellent script for the Proposition, adapted from the fact based book by Matt Bondurant (grandson of one of the film's actual protagonists) the Wettest County in the World, Hillcoat's original movie title. Set in rural America of the prohibition era, Lawless tells what Cave calls "a true myth" about the Bondurant brothers, outlaw heroes of the Virginia hill country, moonshiners who not only defy the law, but as legend has it are invincible because of the many perils that they have overcome and survived that would kill lesser men. None more audacious than middle brother, Forrest (Tom Hardy), who is either blessed or actually is  immortal, his survival skill is something to consider.
 When a big city special agent, Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce) comes into Franklin county, not so much to put a stop to the brothers illegal activities, but looking for part of the take. Hostilities between the Bondurants and the law escalates to also include big city gangsters like Floyd Bonner (Gary Oldman). The conflict eventually grows into outright warfare between the lot of them.
 Things aren't all bloodshed and death, as youngest brother Jack (Shia LeBouf), while trying to prove himself as a worthy heir to the family legacy, also finds himself courting a local preacher's daughter, Bertha (Mia Wasikowska). But the real love story develops between Forrest and Maggie Beauoral (Jessica Chastin), a city girl, who comes to Franklin county looking to outrun a past best left forgotten. The two wounded souls with hard exteriors are able to unleash their inner tenderness together.
 Hillcoat has returned macho cinema to a glorious unflinching place from it's celebrated bloodstained past. His best work recalls the films of maverick hard men directors like Sam Peckinpah, Sam Fuller, Raoul Walsh, and other ambitious auteurs often with a reputation for the lurid, perhaps never more so than with Lawless. Combining elements of the urban gangster film and the western outlaw hero stories, pooled before with mixed results in pictures such as Walter Hill's Last Man Standing and the superior Sam Elliott telefilm You Know My Name, here with greater results. Everything at this juncture is a work of masterful film art, great production and attention to period details, sharp camera work (by Benoit Delhomme), taunt editing, a memorable score and first rate performances.
 Impeccably told in a style that gives a real sense of time and place. We gain a real feel for the people and the locations. This is the kind of movie that you can smell in your mind, from the unkempt Bonderants to the more dandy Rakes.
 LeBouf is reasonably good in the role of Jack, playing a timid, semi-weak young man transformed into a cocky, arrogant hothead. LeBouf is an alright actor who sometimes gets undue flack, however, he lacks the real strength to fully carry a film like this, he's a little too blas to be a good leading man. That's why we have Tom Hardy, who with his portrayal of Forrest Bondurant, fully comes into his own as a movie star, this is the one that should transfix him into a household name. Hardy dominates every scene he is in, he walks away with the movie after kicking it in the teeth and leaving it bludgeoned over the head.
 The supporting cast is just as superb, in fact Lawless couldn't be all that it is without the small, but crucial work done by Jessica Chastain, who is not only one of the most exciting presences on film today, but seems to be as impervious to bad film roles as the Bondurants are to bereavement. Guy Pearce, who has appeared in Hillcoat's two previous masterworks, is ferocious and unrelenting as the essentially strong antagonist, it`s remarkably to think of all the many different type of roles we`ve seen Pearce do in the recent past. Mia Wasikowska with her ethereal beauty and infectious smile adds a perfect counter balance to the testosterone fueled antics on screen. Gary Oldman is always a welcome presence, even if it is just a cameo as it is here, but he looks cool and snazzy with a tommy gun.
 The score by Cave and Warren Ellis is something of genius unto it's elf. Cave, providing new music with a special one off band, cheekily called the Bootleggers, as well as incorporating tunes beautiful sung by Emmylou Harris, the soundtrack not only assists the movie, but helps to more fully tell it's story. Cave and his bootleggers give a thrilling rendition of Lou Reed's Velvet Underground classic "White Light, White Heat", match by a winning bluegrass interruption by Ralph Stanley played over the picture's closing credits. The supplementary CD release of the soundtrack album is via Sony Classical, proving that even the label recognizes the artistry in the accompanying music.
 Lawless is a rip roaring thrilling adventure. A gun totting, gin soaked action drama. It's all that, with the kick of a mule captured in a bottle of pure grain white lightning and white heat.

Since I read the book before seeing the movie, I was skeptical.  However, this movie, while not perfect, kept my attention and delighted me.  Tom Hardy's character did not not have much to work with in the way of the script, but his character is a man of few words who does more with his actions and mannerisms.  Hardy did a good job with his character, creating a facade of invulnerability and toughness with a soft spot for his family and friends.  Shia LaBeouf, whose previous work I have not been a fan of, was actually rather good as the junior Bondurant who is eager to prove himself, but is callow and unsure of himself.  In my view, Guy Pearce, as the foppish, preening, self-absorbed, inhumane deputy from Chicago stole the film.  You really hated him and when Pearce was on the screen, you noticed little else.  Pearce was in the movie Prometheus, and was, in my view, the weak link in that film from an acting perspective, but in this film he really brought his character to life.

From what I can gather about Prohibition and the history of it, "The Wettest Country in the World" is more than a little over the top, and this movie is also over the top.  However, sometimes the Moonshiners did resort to violence and there were lawmen who were corrupt and on the take.  Therefore, this movie is almost certainly a composite of the worst elements of the Prohibition Era, and it is a well-told story that is engaging the interesting.

There is some violence and nudity.  Sensitive and younger viewers should be warned.  However it is not over the top.  All-in-all, a worthy investment for a Friday night.

(Side Note:
The movie is based on a real family of  moon-shining  brothers, and a real incident that ends up in the papers. I believe there is a book out right now, about the real brothers behind the movie LAWLESS, written by the grandson of one of the brothers shown in this movie. I don't want to give away which brother that is.)

I love period film pieces. And the era of the 20's and 30's has always appealed to me as well. So right off the bat, I knew from seeing the trailer, I was bound to rent this  movie sooner or later.

 Funny how the period piece films bring a nostalgia to them, that you actually feel, even if you were not even born at the time the movie/story is taking place.

This was well done as far as giving the viewer the feel for what the Prohibition Days were like down south and how MOONSHINE production was taken very seriously- not just for personal consumption, but for re-sale to others.

Whether it was made and sold to locals or a bigger concern- like gangsters, who would often then re-sell it as well;for the time booze was illegal, moonshine was a big money maker for those creating it.

In reality, and upon looking back at the proliferation of booze that still flowed across America despite the ban - Prohibition not only did not stop the use of alcohol- it drove up the demand.

That was the lesson learned about trying to ban alcohol.

You have to wonder, for the amount of years booze was illegal, how many people were getting rich off the illegality- as well as how many people got sick or died off bad moonshine.

(Going blind or dropping dead were the risk you took, if you bought moonshine  made by someone who didn't know what they were doing.)

But as always, when there is a demand for something- especially something hard to get and illicit- there is big money to be had.

The three tightly knit brothers in LAWLESS jumped on this money making bandwagon early in the game, although the two older brothers try to keep the youngest( Shia Lebouf) from being *too* involved in the business, which he greatly resents.

They definitely love him- and there is a deep thread of loyalty that hold all three together, but the two older brothers don't seem to think their little brother has what it takes to play by the rules in this game.

They make it clear this is not a game one can screw up in.

Mistakes get people shot and often killed. Mistakes can piss off people and stir up trouble.

So, while the money they earn is shared amongst all of them,( they also run a restaurant as well) Shia Lebouf's youth and immaturity cause the brothers to shut him out of things; for his own sake and for the sake of their thriving business.

In the very rural area  where the brothers reside, it is unspoken code that law enforcement looks the other way for local moonshiners - out of courtesy or for a little kickback.

Nobody hassles anyone really. It is a peaceful, predictable life and the townsfolk all seem to get along.

That is,until Guy Pearce's character comes to town.

Pearce has slime ball written all over him.

 A sadistic, city slicker, quirky in a sick & twisted way, he announces himself a federal arm of the law who will hunt down every moonshiner until there are none left.

He has heard about the moonshine business being very lucrative in this area, but more importantly he has heard about the three brothers, in particularly the one brother who is deemed *immortal*( played by a scruffily handsome Tom Hardy).

 This is the local lore and it more or less develops that Hardy is immortal because of the many trials and tribulations he has endured in his young life, particularly when it comes to fighting, particularly with guns.

Guy Pearce is both intrigued and amused by the lore of this brother who can't be killed.

 It should be noted that it is Tom Hardy's character who basically plays the head of the family to the other 2 brothers.  ( Their parents died earlier but that is not depicted in the film.)

He is looked up to by his brothers with great awe, respect and admiration.

 Also,it is always his word that is final in any matters regarding the family- particularly the business end of things.

Guy Pearce  finally gets the chance to meet Hardy and the exchange is an unpleasant one.

One which Hardy makes it clear, that Pearce's presence and  position of law enforcement, don't mean squat to him.

Verbally, he gives Pearce the proverbial slap in the face, and in front of others, no less.

Pearce walks away thinking it is time to take Tom Hardy and his almighty reputation down a notch.

Developing an instant hatred for the man, Pearce is all too eager to be the man to see  the *immortal one* go down in flames.

He becomes hellbent on destroying  not just  Tom Hardy 's character, but also, his moon-shining brothers and their business.

 Kudos for Guy Pearce, for playing one of the creepiest, skin crawling characters to ever show up in story line,with such subtly.

Accolades for Tom Hardy, playing the strong silent type, that tends to delivers cryptic words of wisdom.

The guy who has been to hell and back and is still standing.

This is a character, who never actually looks for a fight, but also never backs down from one.

He always comports himself with confidence, not arrogance.

Sometimes  he has a  certain look or gives off an affect at times, that says that under all that tough veneer, that ability to always seem steel strong, that there might be a layer of emotional vulnerability buried deep inside, underneath it all.

Jessica Chastain is there as a  meaningful character but how meaningful is not realized right away.

While her part is important, she doesn't get to do all that much talking.

Regardless, it becomes obvious she is an integral part of the storyline as it moves along.

Gary Oldman is a personification, a collage if you will,of any and all gangsters of that era, whose names were on the headlines of newspapers, or heard about on the radio, back in the day.

His film time is brief- too brief really. (Especially if you are an Oldman fan.)

Though his screen time is short, it is Oldman's  character's unusual meeting and  interaction with Shia Lebouf , that leaves an impact on Lebouf's character and gives him the guts and incentive to show his brothers he is definitely ready to join their ranks.

He feels he can finally prove to them, he has what it it takes to finally work hands on, in the business, especially doing physical transactions of transporting moon-shine.

Is this film violent?  Yes, it is, and the violence is up close and gritty, but it is not gratuitous violence in my opinion.

It is there to show how ruthless things start to get, in this once sleepy little town, once Guy Pearce sticks his nose into things.

 And trust me- moonshine might be illegal but you will hate Guy Pearce so much, it will just give you all the more reason to root for not just the 3 brothers, but anybody trying to get by, selling their home made moonshine.

The whole movie takes on a new tone and a different pace, once Guy Pearce's character comes to town to make trouble, and a name for himself.

 If you can handle violence and want to see how life in the South was during the prohibition( as opposed to often seeing it  depicted in the big cities)this is a fast paced movie, with a definite amount of suspense, where all the key characters play their parts well and an ending that should satisfy all.

I know that after  seeing this movie, I later went online to look up more about this trio, as well as reviewing articles on the Prohibition era in general.

It might certainly look a lot more glamorous and macho in the movies  of Hollywood,as depicted in the past and present, but there is no doubt that the Prohibition days were colorful, interesting and, often daringly dangerous times indeed.

Critic reviews for 'Lawless' have ranged from good to mediocre, so I was expecting something similar in quality to the turkey that was Public Enemies (Special Edition) [Blu-ray]. Instead, I was very much surprised by the clever acting of Shia Labeouf, Guy Pearce, and Gary Oldman. The studio got it right by underselling the audience with their dull theatrical previews, which leave out the qualities of 'Lawless' that grant it a Tarantinoesque appeal. There are key parts within this movie that make the viewer recoil in disgust, something that is very difficult to pull off outside of slasher movies. Tom Hardy's portrayal of Forrest Bondurant is a bit uneven, as he overacts his role in a puerile sort of way. On the contrary, Guy Pearce's squealy filthiness as Charlie Rakes gives us one of the greatest screen villains since the 'Scorpio Killer' in Dirty Harry [Blu-ray]. Shia Labeouf injects just the right amount of sentimentalism to offset the quease-inducing violence. Gary Oldman impresses, albeit with minimal screen time. Overall, Lawless might be the best Hixploitation film ever made.

Lawless is a gritty, bloody, and powerful gangster tale that takes place in Prohibition-era Virginia. Shia LaBeouf gives his best performance, perhaps of his career, as Jack, the youngest of the Bondurant brothers, who took part in the American dream as back-woods moonshiners. You'll find traces of LaBeouf's typical charm here, but he brings an intensity to the screen I haven't seen from him before. Another fantastic performance is given my Tom Hardy, who plays Jack's older and burlier brother Forrest, who will go to any lengths to uphold his principles. Guy Pearce plays Charley Rakes, the menacing deputy that is trying to put a stop to the Bondurant brother's business, and a character you will instantly hate.

The cinematography in the movie is absolutely gorgeous. John Hillcoat does a terrific job using the Virginian landscape to his advantage, as well as using lighting and colors to their full advantage. I found myself in awe of some of the scenes.

An issue I had with the film is that there were a couple of storylines that could have been developed further, particularly Gary Oldman's and Jessica Chastain's. They both give good performances but I would have liked to see some more screen time from both of them.

Other than that, the movie flows fairly well and comes to a satisfying close. Be warned, there are some gruesome parts that may make your stomach turn. Hillcoat is no stranger to dark and brutal violence, and he doesn't stray away from that with Lawless.

Dark, dank, ugly and cruel is the setting is Franklin County, Virginia where this apparently true story takes place. The cast is what attracts people to attend this movie, but as far as a story is concerned it is all harsh and bloody and poorly developed despite how hard the actors try with the script they've been given (Nick Cave adapted Matt Bondurant's novel `The Wettest County in the World').

The infamous Bondurant brothers - Forrest (Tom Hardy), Howard (Jason Clarke) and Jack (Shia LaBeouf) - assisted by a rickets crippled boy named Crickett (Dane DeHaan) run a successful bootlegging operation during the depression, up in the mountains of Franklin County, Virginia. The only new person to be admitted into the Bondurant clan is Maggie Beauford (Jessica Chastain) who has escaped Chicago nightclub life for the `peace' of the countryside. Also from Chicago comes crooked Special Deputy Charles Rakes (Guy Pearce) who is after a share of the brothers' profits. Compounding their troubles, the local competition is elbowing in on their activities. Forrest's boisterous defiance and Cricket's knack for moonshine production help the brothers gain a local monopoly. When Forrest is wounded as tension with Rakes escalates, Jack, initially the timid one, must prove his worth against local gangster Floyd Banner's (Gary Oldman) mob, and we see him metamorphose into a cocky exhibitionist in his attempts to woo the off-limits preacher's daughter, Bertha (Mia Wasikowski).

The actors make these people memorable, especially Tom Hardy who simply mumbles his way through life unafraid of death or any outside foes. The rest of the cast is strong given the weak script and the overall atmosphere of the Depression era bootlegging business is brought sharply into focus by director John Hillcoat with the aid of a fine musical score by Nick Cave. The story is bleak and cruel and there is a lot of extreme violence. But is does create a mood.  Grady Harp, December 12
