It's been years since the theme of bootleggers was the subject matter in movies. Back in the 70s there was a rush of movies about this subject ranging from the low budget MOONRUNNERS (the movie later turned into the hit TV series THE DUKES OF HAZARD) to the even lower budgeted MOONSHINERS. Even Burt Reynolds took on the subject in WHITE LIGHTNING. But then it kind of disappeared. That all changed when reality TV took a shine (pun intended) to the topic and the film LAWLESS is a result of that renewed interest.

Based loosely on the real life story of the three Bondurant brothers in Franklin County, Virginia, the story focuses on a short period of their lives when bootlegging was their claim to fame and the end result was what was called a war in their home county. Descendants of the real life family have written a book on the subject and that is what the film is based on.

The Bondurant brothers were legends in Franklin County. Oldest brother Forrest (Tom Hardy) was said to be indestructible having crossed paths with death on several occasions. Middle brother Howard (Jason Clarke) has perhaps decided to dip into the family recipe too often but remains the muscle of the group. The youngest brother, Jack (Shia LeBouf) is the upstart, trying to think of ways to impress his older brother Forrest and increase the profits of their bootlegging venture. But Forrest is content to sit back and make the money that he does from their product and pay his bribe money to the local sheriff.

All that changes when a new prosecutor comes to town. Charlie Rakes (Guy Pearce) is part of a task force that was sent to shut down the stills but who in truth is more interested in taking over the entire county's bootlegging business. When Forrest refuses to comply, Rakes sets out to destroy the Bondurant family in any way possible. The result is a violent and bloody confrontation that leaves Forrest wounded but alive and his brothers ready for revenge. But that is not to happen yet.

Jack decides the best way to increase their finances is to begin selling their product to Chicago gangster Floyd Banner (Gary Oldman). With the country dry due to prohibition, Jack can get good money from the mobster in return for supplying the demand the gangsters need for their town. While the brothers may disagree on this item the money does come in handy at the right time.

Rakes' men having been behind the attack on Forrest and the brutalization of a waitress and love interest of Forrest (Jessica Chastain) that same night have left a bad taste in the mouths of the brothers. When they blow up their still and murder Jack's best friend in cold blood, a harmless young boy who had no chance of being a problem to Rakes, the brothers can take no more. An eventual showdown between the corrupt lawman and the bootleggers is inevitable. It's bloody but not overly so and the results are surprising.

LAWLESS does a great job of capturing the era and area that the film takes place in. The back hills of Virginia look beautiful rather than wasted away and yet the people who live there looks as poor as the times the story takes place in. While bootlegging may have paid the bills for poor farmers who made more money this way it was not the glamorous life that say cocaine dealers have been depicted in more modern stories. These were tough men who did what they had to to feed their families and keep their farms. The work was hard and the rewards merely enough to get by. There was no glitz and glamour here.

The acting here is stupendous. Tom Hardy turns in another dynamite performance as a man who uses few words and fewer actions yet carries the threat of violence about him like an aura. His character knows the ways of the world and tries to convey them with little success to his younger brother. LeBouf does a great job as well, depicting a hero worshipping brother who wants to do well by his family yet gets turned down more often than not. Pearce is equal to these two in depicting a bad guy that even law abiding citizens will find themselves hoping gets his due.

The movie doesn't offer a pretty picture of the bootlegging business but it does offer a few new anti-heroes for viewers to root for. You care about this family and the others who faced these problems in the past. It was a violent world that handled things much differently than they are handled today. And that makes for some tremendous storytelling that just might make viewers want to find out more and read about those times.

The Bondurant brothers do what they do best: make damn fine moonshine.  They practically own Franklin County, the residents of whom respect--and fear--Forrest Bondurant, the brothers' ringleader.  But a new lawman, Special Deputy Charlie Rakes, is determined to take his piece of the pie.  But, as Forrest succinctly puts it, the Bondurants "don't lay down for nobody."

The film hinges around youngest brother Jack, played here with surprisingly poise by Shia Lebeouf.  It's basically his story, though, as with Matt Bondurant's source novel THE WETTEST COUNTY IN THE WORLD, the most intriguing character is Forrest.  As portrayed by Tom Hardy, Forrest is a hulking beast of few words, a man tied by honor and loyalty, caught up in his own legend, mostly because it largely happens to be true.  Hardy brings much of the same physicality to Forrest as he did to Bane in THE DARK KNIGHT RISES, creating yet another memorable performance in a career full of them.  As the third brother, Howard, Jason Clarke doesn't have much to do, but does it extremely well; one wishes his role were larger.  As the villain Rakes (a composite of characters from the novel), Guy Pearce is electric; he walks and talks like a big city dandy, but he strikes with the suddenness and venom of a cobra.  Mia Wasikowski doesn't have much to do in her role of a preacher's daughter; as in the novel, her burgeoning relationship with Jack takes a backseat to everything else.  More interesting is the relationship between Forrest and Maggie, portrayed with an air of regality and seduction by Jessica Chastain.  Perhaps most enjoyable of all, if only for its brevity, is Gary Oldman's performance as a gangster whom Jack admires: in his two scenes, Oldman reminds us why he's one of the great villain actors of his generation (in fact, he does this with a single wink).

The script comes from frequent John Hillicoat collaborator Nick Cave, who again (along with Warren Ellis) provides an exquisitely haunting score.  The trio of Hillicoat, Cave, and Ellis gave us the superb THE PROPOSITION (Pearce's contributions cannot be ignored, either); if LAWLESS doesn't quite equal THE PROPOSITION's level of violence, it's not for lack of trying.  This is a violent film.  The violence isn't constant, but it's realistic and powerful, as it should be in this sort of film.  The story is, of course, somewhat true; if Bondurant's book is a fictionalization of his family's history, then Hillicoat's film is a fictionalization of the book.  Cave's script, Hillicoat's direction, and the actors' performances hold fast to this element of truth: this film, at its core, isn't about moonshine, but humanity.  And sometimes, humanity can be an ugly, violent thing.

Lawless is an early 1930's period piece about the bootlegging business between three hick brothers who try to maintain their moonshine business with cops and competition crawling up their asses. This movie is very pretty to look at, the music is well done and interesting (covering newer songs to sound older), and the actors sell their roles pretty well. The problem I had with Lawless though was the overall story, tone, characters, and pacing; and here's why:

-Characters: So our protagonist in this film is the youngest of the brothers who's grown up a coward who wants to be a tough guy businessman like his brothers, however he doesn't really find his balls until 20 minutes before the movie's over and makes dumb decisions throughout the film that jeopardizes his family. So we have a flawed protagonist, not really a big deal, it sort of adds depth to him, although all the depth that's given to him makes his character your standard cookie-cutter underdog ripped from countless Hollywood stories and not much else. The middle brother is basically just the family wildcard, and the oldest brother is the quiet reserved badass that pretty much runs the family business himself.

So this is your trio of characters the movie is 'based on', there's almost no depth to any of them if you've seen Hollywood underdog gangster movies before. Then you have sub-characters, such as Rickety Cricket who was a former priest turned cokehea-wait, wrong Rickety Cricket. Crickety Ricket, who is the token smart guy, fixes the bootlegging equipment and machinery and is the youngest brother's timid nice friend who ends up being the second act martyr to move along to the third act. The youngest brother's love interest also plays a small role simply as 'love interest', and she just giggles and repeats "if my daddy were here", "my daddy don't like you", "my daddy this", "my daddy that", etc. You also have Gary Oldman, who was barely in the film and his name was slapped on for marketing purposes as the intimidating mobster who buys from the brothers for no reason other than he recognized the younger brother's face.

But now onto my favorite character: the evil FBI agent who wears all black, looks like a pale sickly Nazi, and pretty much tortures anyone who crosses him, all the while the police officers turn a blind eye. Early in the movie he asks someone "do you think I'm stupid?", which he apparently is since he does nothing the entire film but piss off the entire town (including the police officers). Also, you're supposed to believe that in the 1920's everyone in a Southern town that wasn't a criminal was a total coward. The agent saunters around town and terrorizes the populace without anyone raising questions or just shooting the guy. Sure he was a federal agent, but I think murdering the town cripple in cold blood would lead to his titles being stripped away from him at least. Sure there was some message about how fear controls people, but that's more applicable now with people sitting inside watching the media, not in the 1930's where people were still settling across the country.

So there's little depth to any of the characters, hell even Pulp Fiction had more character depth to it. But what about the story? Well the story is basically the agent slowly snaking his way farther and farther up the brother's asses until they decide to retaliate, which is the end of the movie. The story itself is kind of interesting, family protecting their business and what have you. One thing that was weird about the pace was how predictable it got. After the agent arrives into town, there would be a few 5 minute scenes where the youngest brother and his love interest would be flirting, and then SUDDENLY 20 MINUTES OF GRAPHIC VIOLENCE & DRAMA!!!! There was virtually no build-up to the climax of the movie because the pace never changed from STOP-GO-STOP-GO.

There were also a few scenes that were either plain stupid or plain annoying. Like for instance the police find the bootleg still, and the brothers never think to just burn the place down while the cops are there. Also in that scene, the youngest brother comes across the agent who's in his mercy, and before this scene, the agent beat the royal s*** out of the brother. So what does the brother do now in this opportune moment? Step on the agent's face and call him a queer or something. He doesn't break the guys teeth, he doesn't bruise up the guys face or kick him in the balls, no, our hero does nothing but some anti-climactic love tap then walks away. Also at the end of the movie, the youngest brother is pissed since his token smart best friend is dead, and wants to shoot the agent. So what does he do? He goes up to a police roadblock where the agent is among a dozen cops, and points his gun at all of them, and doesn't get shot immediately. No, the bad guy has to slither out from the darkness (literally) and shoot the brother. It's dumb, stupid, Hollywood s*** like this that pisses me off from these kinds of movies.

So it was entertaining most of the time in a 'how far will they take it this time' sorta way, it almost felt like a graphic novel or something due to the violence. Again, the music was great, which makes sense considering it was from the talented Nick Cave who also scored the infinitely better period piece: The Assassination of Jesse James. The acting was decent and so was the whole design, it was just unrealistic, shallow, and stupid a lot of the time.

  The Bondurant brothers are the owners and operators of the premier bootlegging operation in Franklin County, Virginia. Jack, the youngest (portrayed by Shia LaBouef) is assisting Howard (played by Jason Clarke) and Forrest (played by Tom Hardy) when he witnesses a shooting. The gunman, Floyd Banner (played by Gary Oldman), locks eyes with young Jack before he departs for the operation's headquarters. Once there, Forrest (Hardy) hires a new waitress. Her name is Maggie Beauford (played by Jessica Chastain) and she is a former dancer who's recently moved to Franklin County from Chicago. Shortly after that, the bootlegging business is confronted with an obstacle. Charlie Rakes, another new arrival and a Special Deputy. Rakes (played by Guy Pearce) tells Forrest that, from now on, he and his superiors will be given a percentage of the profits form their business. Forrest, as expected, sends Rakes away and threatens to kill him if he returns. After his departure, Forrest organizes a meeting of his colleagues in the illegal alcohol business. His hope is to rally them into a resistance movement. "Bootleggers of the world unite" if you will. While they are receptive, initially, it's only a matter of time before they capitulate to Deputy Rakes. In the meantime, Jack has become enamored with Bertha Minnix. Bertha (played by Mia Wasikowska) is the daughter of a local German Baptist preacher who forbids Bertha from seeing Jack once he attends one of his services drunk and leaves abruptly.

  This film is supposedly based on a historical novel written by the grandson of LaBouef's character. I don't know how faithful the film is to the novel or how historically accurate the novel is, but as far as I'm concerned, the movie failed. I am not at all surprised by the fact that Tom Hardy is talented as he has demonstrated it on numerous occasions. Maybe Lawless would be more engrossing if its release had predated the HBO series about Prohibition era bootlegging, Boardwalk Empire. Maybe not. All I can say is that I was underwhelmed. Maybe you won't be.

Lawless started out as a form on genealogy. Matt Bondurant knew his grandfather Jack Bondurant and his grand-uncles Forrest and Howard were bootleggers. This led to the historical novel The Wettest County in the World (2008). The book wound up in the hands of director John Hillcoat (The Road, The Proposition).
"Bootlegging sort of drew the Bondurants into this crazy kind of world of corruption and lawlessness ironically," Hillcoat said. "But then mostly they survived, they got through it all and actually went on to have businesses and children. And traditionally the gangster film teaches us that we've to  pay for our sins. Usually the gangster is shot down in a blaze of glory and doesn't get up again."
In the movie Lawless, the Bondurant brothers have created this almost immortal image. And according to how much of this actually happened, they certainly live up to that image.
It's 1931 and the brothers are the most successful bootleggers in Franklin County, Virginia. Cricket Pate runs their bar, which is a cover for their illegal venture.
Maggie Beauford, a dancer from Chicago, arrives and becomes their new waitress.
The brothers have been selling moonshine to everyone from clergy to law enforcement. Special Deputy Charley Rakes confronts Forrest and tells him things will be changing, that all profits made by bootleggers will stop. All bootleggers but the Bondurant brothers fold to Rakes demands.
Lawless is an intoxicating film, filled with brutal imagery and you can't help but pull for the backwoods boys.

LAWLESS is inspired by the essentially true and fascinating adventures of the legendary, seemingly "indestructible," Bondurant Brothers, bootleggers in Prohibition-era Virginia, who went to war against corrupt politicians and, in doing so, became heroes to their neighbors.

Shia LeBeouf, Tom Hardy and Jason Clarke play the backwoods siblings.  They only want to make an "honest" living, selling their moonshine at a fair price to people in their community, but when a crooked special deputy (Guy Pearce) demands a large cut of their action, the brothers refuse and that leads to violence, torture and murder.

Adapted for the screen by composer Nick Cave from a novel (based on fact) by Matt Bondurant, grandson of the character played in the film by LeBeouf, LAWLESS features a cast of intriguing, multi-dimensional characters, portrayed by some of the most talented actors in films today.  Jessica Chastain, as an emotionally damaged woman from Chicago who comes to work for the brothers, Mia Wasikowska, as a Mennonite girl courted by LeBeouf, and Gary Oldman, playing a big city gangster on the run, are also memorable in their roles

Director John Hillcoat and his team have flawlessly re-created backwoods Virginia of the early 1930s.  His action sequences are well staged and riveting.

Unfortunately, the film does have several slow spots, caused by the fact that the screenplay lacks focus.  Too much time is spent on two romantic subplots (i.e. LeBeouf/Wasikowska, Hardy/Chastain), which are, in themselves, touching, but these sequences distract from the primary storyline, the conflict between the brothers and Pearce's character.  LeBeouf serves as the narrator of the movie and has top billing, yet the filmmakers never make clear whether this is his story or Hardy's.

Anchor Bay Entertainment has issued LAWLESS in a 3-disc (Blu-Ray/DVD/Digital) combo pack.  Extras include audio commentary by director Hillcoat and author Matt Bondurant, deleted scenes, a music video and several featurettes that discuss the real brothers and the making of the film.
